trans-unit.source: Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Resource Management | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Resource Management | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn about using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows to manage Azure resources using the Azure CLI arm mode.
trans-unit.target: Learn about using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows to manage Azure resources using the Azure CLI arm mode.

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Resource Management
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Resource Management

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to use the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI) in the **arm** mode to create, manage, and delete services on the command line of Mac, Linux, and Windows computers.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to use the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI) in the **arm** mode to create, manage, and delete services on the command line of Mac, Linux, and Windows computers.

trans-unit.source: You can perform the same tasks using the various libraries of the Azure SDKs, with PowerShell, and using the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can perform the same tasks using the various libraries of the Azure SDKs, with PowerShell, and using the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Azure resource management enables you to create a group of resources -- virtual machines, websites, databases, and so on -- as a single deployable unit.
trans-unit.target: Azure resource management enables you to create a group of resources -- virtual machines, websites, databases, and so on -- as a single deployable unit.

trans-unit.source: You can then deploy, update, or delete all of the resources for your application in a single, coordinated operation.
trans-unit.target: You can then deploy, update, or delete all of the resources for your application in a single, coordinated operation.

trans-unit.source: You describe your group resources in a JSON template for deployment and then can use that template for different environments such as testing, staging and production.
trans-unit.target: You describe your group resources in a JSON template for deployment and then can use that template for different environments such as testing, staging and production.

trans-unit.source: Imperative and declarative approaches
trans-unit.target: Imperative and declarative approaches

trans-unit.source: As with the [service management mode (**asm**)](../virtual-machines-command-line-tools.md), the **arm** mode of the Azure CLI gives you commands that create resources imperatively on the command line.
trans-unit.target: As with the [service management mode (**asm**)](../virtual-machines-command-line-tools.md), the **arm** mode of the Azure CLI gives you commands that create resources imperatively on the command line.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you type `azure group create <groupname> <location>` you are asking Azure to create a resource group, and with `azure group deployment create <resourcegroup> <deploymentname>` you are instructing Azure to create a deployment of any number of items and place them in a group.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you type `azure group create <groupname> <location>` you are asking Azure to create a resource group, and with `azure group deployment create <resourcegroup> <deploymentname>` you are instructing Azure to create a deployment of any number of items and place them in a group.

trans-unit.source: Because each type of resource has imperative commands, you can chain them together to create fairly complex deployments.
trans-unit.target: Because each type of resource has imperative commands, you can chain them together to create fairly complex deployments.

trans-unit.source: However, using resource group _templates_ that describe a resource group is a declarative approach that is far more powerful, allowing you to automate complex deployments of (almost) any number of resources for (almost) any purpose.
trans-unit.target: However, using resource group _templates_ that describe a resource group is a declarative approach that is far more powerful, allowing you to automate complex deployments of (almost) any number of resources for (almost) any purpose.

trans-unit.source: When using templates, the only imperative command is to deploy one.
trans-unit.target: When using templates, the only imperative command is to deploy one.

trans-unit.source: For a general overview of templates, resources, and resource groups, see [Azure Resource Group Overview](resource-groups-overview).
trans-unit.target: For a general overview of templates, resources, and resource groups, see [Azure Resource Group Overview](resource-groups-overview).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] In addition to command-specific options documented below and on the command line, there are three options that can be used to view detailed output such as request options and status codes.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] In addition to command-specific options documented below and on the command line, there are three options that can be used to view detailed output such as request options and status codes.

trans-unit.source: The -v parameter provides verbose output, and the -vv parameter provides even more detailed verbose output.
trans-unit.target: The -v parameter provides verbose output, and the -vv parameter provides even more detailed verbose output.

trans-unit.source: The --json option will output the result in raw json format, and is very useful for scripting scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The --json option will output the result in raw json format, and is very useful for scripting scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Usage with the --json switch is very common, and is an important part of both obtaining and understanding results from Azure CLI operations that return resource information, status, and logs and also using templates.
trans-unit.target: Usage with the --json switch is very common, and is an important part of both obtaining and understanding results from Azure CLI operations that return resource information, status, and logs and also using templates.

trans-unit.source: You may want to install JSON parser tools such as **jq** or **jsawk** or use your favorite language library.
trans-unit.target: You may want to install JSON parser tools such as **jq** or **jsawk** or use your favorite language library.

trans-unit.source: Usage requirements
trans-unit.target: Usage requirements

trans-unit.source: The set-up requirements to use the **arm** mode with the Azure CLI are:
trans-unit.target: The set-up requirements to use the **arm** mode with the Azure CLI are:

trans-unit.source: an Azure account ([get a free trial here](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/))
trans-unit.target: an Azure account ([get a free trial here](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/))

trans-unit.source: installing the Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: installing the Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: [configuring the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli-connect.md) to use an Azure Active Directory identity or a Service Principal
trans-unit.target: [configuring the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli-connect.md) to use an Azure Active Directory identity or a Service Principal

trans-unit.source: Once you have an account and have installed the Azure CLI, you must
trans-unit.target: Once you have an account and have installed the Azure CLI, you must

trans-unit.source: switch to the **arm** mode by typing `azure config mode arm`.
trans-unit.target: switch to the **arm** mode by typing `azure config mode arm`.

trans-unit.source: Log in to your Azure account by typing `azure login` and using your work or school identity at the prompts
trans-unit.target: Log in to your Azure account by typing `azure login` and using your work or school identity at the prompts

trans-unit.source: Now type `azure` to see a list of the top level commands described in the sections below.
trans-unit.target: Now type `azure` to see a list of the top level commands described in the sections below.

trans-unit.source: azure account: Manage your account information and publish settings
trans-unit.target: azure account: Manage your account information and publish settings

trans-unit.source: Your Azure subscription information is used by the tool to connect to your account.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure subscription information is used by the tool to connect to your account.

trans-unit.source: This information can be obtained from the Azure portal in a publish settings file as described here.
trans-unit.target: This information can be obtained from the Azure portal in a publish settings file as described here.

trans-unit.source: You can import the publish settings file as a persistent local configuration setting that the tool will use for subsequent operations.
trans-unit.target: You can import the publish settings file as a persistent local configuration setting that the tool will use for subsequent operations.

trans-unit.source: You only need to import your publish settings once.
trans-unit.target: You only need to import your publish settings once.

trans-unit.source: List the imported subscriptions
trans-unit.target: List the imported subscriptions

trans-unit.source: Show details about a subscription
trans-unit.target: Show details about a subscription

trans-unit.source: Set the current subscription
trans-unit.target: Set the current subscription

trans-unit.source: Remove a subscription or environment, or clear all of the stored account and environment info
trans-unit.target: Remove a subscription or environment, or clear all of the stored account and environment info

trans-unit.target: Commands to manage your account environment

trans-unit.source: azure network: Commands to manage network resources

trans-unit.target: Commands to manage virtual networks

trans-unit.target: Allows to create a new virtual network.

trans-unit.source: In the following example we create a virtual network named newvnet for resource group myresourcegroup in the West US region.
trans-unit.target: In the following example we create a virtual network named newvnet for resource group myresourcegroup in the West US region.

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage probes of a load balancer
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage probes of a load balancer

trans-unit.source: Create the probe configuration for health status in the load balancer.
trans-unit.target: Create the probe configuration for health status in the load balancer.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind to run this command, your load balancer requires a frontend-ip resource (Check out command "azure network frontend-ip" to assign an ip address to load balancer).
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind to run this command, your load balancer requires a frontend-ip resource (Check out command "azure network frontend-ip" to assign an ip address to load balancer).

trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.target: Commands to manage frontend ip configurations of a load balancer

trans-unit.target: Creates a frontend IP configuration to an existing load balancer set.

trans-unit.target: Allows to update an existing configuration of a frontend IP.The command below adds a public IP called mypubip5 to an existing load balancer frontend IP named myfrontendip.

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage backend address pools of a load balancer
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage backend address pools of a load balancer

trans-unit.source: Create a backend address pool for a load balancer.
trans-unit.target: Create a backend address pool for a load balancer.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: A backend address pool range is how a load balancer will know what resources to route incoming network traffic from its endpoint using Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: A backend address pool range is how a load balancer will know what resources to route incoming network traffic from its endpoint using Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: After you create and name the backend address pool range (See command "azure network lb address-pool create"), you need to add the endpoints which are now defined by a resource called "network interfaces".
trans-unit.target: After you create and name the backend address pool range (See command "azure network lb address-pool create"), you need to add the endpoints which are now defined by a resource called "network interfaces".

trans-unit.source: To configure the backend address range, you will need at least one "network interface"(See "azure network lb nic" command line for more details).
trans-unit.target: To configure the backend address range, you will need at least one "network interface"(See "azure network lb nic" command line for more details).

trans-unit.source: In the following example it was used a previously created "nic1" network interface to create the backend address pool range.
trans-unit.target: In the following example it was used a previously created "nic1" network interface to create the backend address pool range.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: Removes a network interface from backend IP address pool range.
trans-unit.target: Removes a network interface from backend IP address pool range.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: List backend IP address pool range for a specific resource group
trans-unit.target: List backend IP address pool range for a specific resource group

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: network lb address-pool delete [options] <resource-group> <lb-name>
trans-unit.target: network lb address-pool delete [options] <resource-group> <lb-name>

trans-unit.source: Removes the backend IP pool range resource from load balancer.
trans-unit.target: Removes the backend IP pool range resource from load balancer.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage load balancer rules
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage load balancer rules

trans-unit.source: Create load balancer rules.
trans-unit.target: Create load balancer rules.

trans-unit.source: You can create a load balancer rule configuring the frontend endpoint for the load balancer and the backend address pool range which will receive the incoming network traffic.
trans-unit.target: You can create a load balancer rule configuring the frontend endpoint for the load balancer and the backend address pool range which will receive the incoming network traffic.

trans-unit.source: Settings also include the ports for frontend IP endpoint and ports for the backend address pool range.
trans-unit.target: Settings also include the ports for frontend IP endpoint and ports for the backend address pool range.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a load balancer rule, the frontend endpoint listening to port 80 TCP and load balancing network traffic sending to port 8080 for the backend address pool range.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a load balancer rule, the frontend endpoint listening to port 80 TCP and load balancing network traffic sending to port 8080 for the backend address pool range.

trans-unit.source: Updates an existing load balancer rule set in a specific resource group.
trans-unit.target: Updates an existing load balancer rule set in a specific resource group.

trans-unit.source: In the following example we changed the rule name from mylbrule to mynewlbrule.
trans-unit.target: In the following example we changed the rule name from mylbrule to mynewlbrule.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: Lists all load balancer rules configured for a load balancer in a specific resource group.
trans-unit.target: Lists all load balancer rules configured for a load balancer in a specific resource group.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: Deletes a load balancer rule.
trans-unit.target: Deletes a load balancer rule.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.target: Commands to manage load balancer inbound NAT rules

trans-unit.source: Creates a inbound NAT rule for load balancer.
trans-unit.target: Creates a inbound NAT rule for load balancer.

trans-unit.source: In the example below we created a NAT rule from frontend IP (which was previously defined.
trans-unit.target: In the example below we created a NAT rule from frontend IP (which was previously defined.

trans-unit.source: See "azure network frontend-ip" command for more details) with a inbound listening port and outbound port which the load balancer will send the network traffic.
trans-unit.target: See "azure network frontend-ip" command for more details) with a inbound listening port and outbound port which the load balancer will send the network traffic.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: Updates an existing inbound nat rule.In the following example we changed the inbound listening port from 80 to 81.
trans-unit.target: Updates an existing inbound nat rule.In the following example we changed the inbound listening port from 80 to 81.

trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage public ip addresses
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage public ip addresses

trans-unit.source: Creates a public ip resource.
trans-unit.target: Creates a public ip resource.

trans-unit.source: You will create the public ip resource and associate to a domain name.
trans-unit.target: You will create the public ip resource and associate to a domain name.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: -h, --help output usage information
trans-unit.target: -h, --help output usage information

trans-unit.source: -v, --verbose use verbose output
trans-unit.target: -v, --verbose use verbose output

trans-unit.source: --json use json output
trans-unit.target: --json use json output

trans-unit.source: -g, --resource-group <resource-group> the name of the resource group
trans-unit.target: -g, --resource-group <resource-group> the name of the resource group

trans-unit.source: -n, --name
trans-unit.target: -n, --name

trans-unit.source: the name of the public ip
trans-unit.target: the name of the public ip

trans-unit.source: -l, --location
trans-unit.target: -l, --location

trans-unit.source: the location
trans-unit.target: the location

trans-unit.source: -d, --domain-name-label <domain-name-label> the domain name label.
trans-unit.target: -d, --domain-name-label <domain-name-label> the domain name label.

trans-unit.source: This set DNS to <domain-name-label>.
trans-unit.target: This set DNS to <domain-name-label>.

trans-unit.source: .cloudapp.azure.com
trans-unit.target: .cloudapp.azure.com

trans-unit.source: -a, --allocation-method <allocation-method> the allocation method [Static][Dynamic]
trans-unit.target: -a, --allocation-method <allocation-method> the allocation method [Static][Dynamic]

trans-unit.source: -i, --idletimeout
trans-unit.target: -i, --idletimeout

trans-unit.source: the idle timeout in minutes
trans-unit.target: the idle timeout in minutes

trans-unit.source: -f, --reverse-fqdn <reverse-fqdn> the reverse fqdn
trans-unit.target: -f, --reverse-fqdn <reverse-fqdn> the reverse fqdn

trans-unit.source: -t, --tags
trans-unit.target: -t, --tags

trans-unit.source: the list of tags.
trans-unit.target: the list of tags.

trans-unit.source: Can be multiple.
trans-unit.target: Can be multiple.

trans-unit.source: In the format of "name=value".
trans-unit.target: In the format of "name=value".

trans-unit.source: Name is required and value is optional.
trans-unit.target: Name is required and value is optional.

trans-unit.source: For example, -t tag1=value1;tag2
trans-unit.target: For example, -t tag1=value1;tag2

trans-unit.source: -s, --subscription
trans-unit.target: -s, --subscription

trans-unit.source: the subscription identifier
trans-unit.target: the subscription identifier

trans-unit.source: Updates the properties of an existing public ip resource.
trans-unit.target: Updates the properties of an existing public ip resource.

trans-unit.source: In the following example we changed the public IP address from Dynamic to Static.
trans-unit.target: In the following example we changed the public IP address from Dynamic to Static.

trans-unit.source: Parameter options:
trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.source: network public-ip list [options] <resource-group>
trans-unit.target: network public-ip list [options] <resource-group>

trans-unit.source: Lists all public IP resources within a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Lists all public IP resources within a resource group.

trans-unit.target: Parameter options:

trans-unit.target: Displays public ip properties for a public ip resource within a resource group.
